title-group.label: Chapter 23
title-group.title: Local Governance of Sustainability Transition in Community-Scale Solar Water Pumping Systems in Indonesia

sec.title: Sita Rahmani
sec.p: studied master and doctoral degree in environmental planning and policy science at the School of Environment and Society, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan. She has worked as a research assistant in various projects of urban and regional planning, including projects funded by foreign university, ministry, and various government agencies in Indonesia. Her main research interests include regional development, environmental management, and local renewable energy.

sec.title: Takehiko Murayama
sec.p: is a professor of environmental planning and policy science at Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan. He received a PhD in social engineering, then served academic and professional appointments at Waseda University and Fukushima University (Japan), and visiting professor at University of British Columbia (Canada) and Rutgers University (USA). His research fields include risk management and communication, environmental impact assessment for renewable energy facilities and international cooperation.

sec.title: Shigeo Nishikizawa
sec.p: is an associate professor of environmental planning and policy of the School of Environment and Society, Tokyo Institute of Technology (Tokyo Tech). He received a PhD in social engineering from Tokyo Tech, and then served as a research associate. He was also appointed as a lecturer at University of Shiga Prefecture, Japan. His research interests cover environmental impact assessment, consensus building, and social acceptance of renewable energies.

sec.title: Muhammad Sani Roychansyah
sec.p: is an associate professor of urban planning, design, and development at Department of Architecture and Planning, Universitas Gadjah Mada. He graduated from Architecture UGM, and continued his master and doctorate at Tohoku University, Japan. He collaborated with researches at ETH Zurich, Politecnico di Torino, University of Warsaw, and several Japanese institutions. His research interests are related to sustainable urban development and contemporary studies of built environment.

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Sustainability transition emerges in various types of community-scale projects. Indonesia has been actively implementing solar water pumping systems (SWPS) since 1982. However, for almost four decades, SWPS, as a niche innovation, have not achieved significant adoption of solar technology in the water utility sector. This study aimed to assess local governance aspects of SWPS in the context of sustainability transition from two perspectives: internal niche management and local actors. We assessed nine SWPS projects in Yogyakarta Province, Indonesia, using structured interviews that were analyzed using descriptive statistics and qualitative content analysis. The results showed that the discontinuation of support made SWPS unsustainable, operating only for an average of 4 years. Crucial operational factors included electrical damage, insufficient training, and lack of funds for damage repair. The iterative process of learning, network building, and vision did not eventuate. SWPS have direct benefit on the water supply; however, technological performance feedback related to the karst environment was insufficiently addressed and the network of actors did not expand to higher levels of local government. SWPS were viewed as an unreliable technology; hence, there was no vision for applying SWPS as a water utility. Solar photovoltaic pumps need strong support to compete with diesel and electrical water utility pumps. To achieve sustainability transition, it is imperative to generate vision, promote policy change, and build committed networks within local government rather than simply replicate the number of project installations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Efforts for sustainableGovernancelocalSustainability transitiontransitionTransitions often begin with niche innovationsInnovations (Geels & Schot, 2007) carried out in local context and expected to scale up for broader societal changes in a regime selection environment (Schot & Geels, 2008). Many sustainability experiments have been implemented in a societal context with the expectation of substantial sustainability gains in not only environmental but also social and economic aspects (Sengers et al., 2019). Community-scale solar water pumping system (SWPS)Solar water pumping system (SWPS) is one example of an innovationInnovations to create a more sustainable water–energy system. The technologyTechnologies combines a pump that operates on electricity generated by photovoltaic (PV) cells. It is an ideal alternative to electricity- and diesel-based pumps that rely heavily on fossil fuel (Li et al., 2017).

In Indonesia, SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) have been actively implemented since 1982 (UNESCAP, 1991). However, the total number of projects is unknown and the official evaluation documents are lacking. Data from Lorentz (Lorentz, n.d.), a German supplier of solar pumps, reported approximately 189 SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) projects across Indonesia during 2005–2021. Figure 23.1 shows the distribution of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) projects per province on the bivariate thematic ratio map for electrification (Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources Republic of Indonesia, 2019) and decent drinking water1 (BPS Indonesia, 2019). It is shown in the map that SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) is applied in regions with low electricity and water access, such as Nusa Tenggara Timur (54 projects), as well as regions that have access to both, such as Java Island (19 projects). This provides insight that the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) has become an interesting option across rural Indonesia, promising an affordable water supply, energy security, and environmental protection.Fig. 23.1
Distribution of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) projects in the bivariate map of electrification to decent drinking water ratio
An Indonesian map depicts the distribution of S W P S according to electrification and clean water ratio. It represents the maximum number of S W P S used in areas with limited access to electricity and water.

To date, the practices of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) in Indonesia have not accumulated toward significant adoption of renewable energyRenewable energies (RE). The internal process of innovationInnovations to transitionTransitions has been addressed through a framework of strategic niche management, that is, governance approach to create favorable environment to enhance further developmentDevelopments of new technologyTechnologies (Kemp et al., 1998; Schot & Geels, 2008; Seyfang et al., 2014; Smith et al., 2016). TransformationsTransformations of multiple projects at localGovernancelocals level require aggregation, coordinationCoordination, and adjustment to propel the technological trajectory of this emerging field (Geels & Raven, 2006) as illustrated in Fig. 23.2. TransitionTransitions from a niche innovationInnovations to a broader application needs support in the form of wider institutional changes and system innovationsInnovations by a variety of participants and across governance levels, from national to regional and local (Dobravec et al., 2021). Continuing support from an institution is one of the important factors to sustain community energy projects (Rahmani et al., 2020).Fig. 23.2
Niche trajectory by local projects. (Adapted from Geels & Raven, 2006)
A process flow of Niche trajectory through internal niche management, requires aggregation, coordination, and adjustment to reach the technological trajectory.

As a niche innovationInnovations, SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) have hardly moved from experimentation to mainstream adoption in the water utility sector. In the Local GovernmentLocal governments Water Utility’s (PDAM) energy efficiency guidelines and strategic plan of 2018–2022 (Ministry of Public Work Republic of Indonesia, 2014, 2017), there is no specific plan to adopt SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) nor RE. Several PDAM had considered using solar powerPowers (PERPAMSI, 2016; Samudra, 2021); however, to the best of our knowledge, none is yet to be built. Energy aspect is crucial because PDAM has issues of unstable powerPowers supply from the national grid (Nurmalia et al., 2006). Energy is needed at every stage of the water service cycle (Plappally & Lienhard, 2012) and often accounts for the largest (approximately 55%) proportion of operating costs (IRENA, 2015). RE, specifically solar PV in water utilities, offers opportunities to improve energy security. One example of this is the Valley Center Municipal Water District in California, where 1.1 MW solar PV was applied to supply 20% of the electricity required by the utility’s largest pumping station (IRENA, 2015). However, in Indonesia, throughout almost four decades of experience implementing SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS), adoption of this technologyTechnologies in water utility operations has not emerged.

Various aspects of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) in Indonesia have been studied in the last few years. Most papers explored design analysis, technical challenges, and economic feasibilities, such as in Gunungkidul and Banten (Arifin et al., 2018; Setiawan et al., 2014a, b; Simamora, 2020). DevelopmentDevelopments processes have been evaluated regarding implementation (Primawan & Iswanjono, 2019; Riyanto et al., 2021; Setiawan et al., 2014a, b) and the participationParticipation of diverse stakeholdersStakeholders (Wahyuni et al., 2015), which comes from Gunungkidul and Ponorogo. Recently, a paper investigated some socioeconomic impacts of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) projects in Gunungkidul (Rahmani et al., 2021). Despite the growing body of studies on SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) in Indonesia, examination of localGovernancelocals governance aspects has not been sufficiently reported. Initiative from government is crucial for growth and developmentDevelopments of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS), as reported in India, where large-scale implementation took place across country, targeting 1 million SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) by 2021 (Rathore et al., 2018). In Indonesia, there is a gap in literature about SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) in the context of governance aspect and sustainability transitionSustainability transitions into a broader water utility application.

This study aimed to assess localGovernancelocals governance aspects in SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) in the context of sustainability transitionSustainability transitions. We define local governance at two levels: internal niche managementInternal niche management and local actors, including local governmentLocal governments and the implementing organization. We argue that the lack of a supportive environment from local actors contributes to the unsustainability of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) in the water utility sector. To show this, we test our hypothesis in a case study. We selected Gunungkidul RegencyRegencies in YogyakartaYogyakarta Province, because several institutions there have actively implemented SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) during 1986–2017. The district comprises a rural region (94%) (BPS Kabupaten Gunungkidul, 2019) and has a karst landscape, which is formed by the dissolution of carbonate rocks, and prolonged water issues. High rock solubility results in caves and extensive underground aquifers (Bakalowicz, 2005). Water is sourced from caves, deep wells, or springs that are often off-grid and far from settlements. SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) project was expected to solve the water problem. The projects were replicated in many villages, but some local articles reported that systems became fully nonfunctional after several years of operation (Kusuma, 2008; WKM, 2009). Official documents concerning the evaluation and performance status were lacking. We investigated nine SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) projects and interviewed community-based organizations (CBOs), the implementing organizations, village and subdistrict leaders, and local governmentsLocal governments, and conducted a qualitative analysis of their responses.

The novelty of this paper is based on two key points. First, it fills the gap in the current literature dedicated to community-scale SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) regarding the major issue of support systems that enable sustainability transitionSustainability transitions. Second, the research is innovative in taking the perspective and analysis of institutional arrangementsInstitutional arrangements from each actor in the local stakeholderStakeholders cohort. As a study case, SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) in Gunungkidul represents the typology of small-scale (<1 MW) solar PV for productive use, specifically for rural community water supply. Worldwide, India has been the major implementer of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) for agricultural farmsFarms (Chandel et al., 2015), while in developed countries, the applications are commonly for ranchland, livestock, and vacation homes (Meah et al., 2008a, b). As an RE technologyTechnologies, SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) produces the direct benefit of water, not electricity. Therefore, the technologyTechnologies performance is strongly associated with an underground aquifer and challenging environmental conditions such as the karst landscape of Gunungkidul.

sec.title: Analytical Framework
sec.p:
To the best of our knowledge, scholars have not assessed SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) in Indonesia through a niche management framework and the institutional arrangementsInstitutional arrangements of local actors; hence, we decided to add these considerations in the research as shown in Fig. 23.3. We hypothesized that the lack of a supportive environment, from local actors to internal niche, leads to SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) malfunction and eventually difficulty in adopting the technologyTechnologies. The first level of analysis is the internal niche. The definitions of niche management process are as follows: (a) LearningLearningprocess includes the articulation of needs, problems, and possibilities at multiple dimensions. (b) Network building contributes to niche developmentDevelopments when it has diverse actors providing multiple views and can mobilize commitment and resources. (c) Visions and expectations are crucial to drive the nurturing process and it should be shared among actors (Kemp et al., 1998; Schot & Geels, 2008; Seyfang et al., 2014).Fig. 23.3
Analytical framework
A chart depicts the malfunction of the S W P S project in Indonesia due to a lack of a supportive environment, from local actors to niche management, which leads to difficulties in the water utility sector.

The second step of analysis is the connection of niche with the institutional arrangementsInstitutional arrangements of localGovernancelocals actors. In our analysis, local actors consist of local governmentLocal governments and the implementing organizations. Since the democratizations process in 1998, central government has decentralized many of its function to local governmentLocal governments, which is divided into autonomous provinces, districts (or regenciesRegencies, kabupaten), and municipalities (kota) (Usman, 2001). In districts comprising rural areas, there are smaller government administrative units called subdistricts (kecamatan) and villages (desa). To fully understand the context, we added an important actor in the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) process: the implementing organizations that drive SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS)developmentDevelopments, such as universities, nonprofit organizations (NPOs), the national agencyAgencies, and international donors. We analyzed the actors’ governance aspect based on three indicators: policyPolicies, structure, and management. The definitions are as follows: (1) PolicyPoliciesand institutional mandate is how government follows a certain method to achieve the desired result; (2) Structure means allocation of responsibilityResponsibilities and budgeting; and (3) Management focuses on the government’s relationship with society, particularly in regard to engaging in SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) issues (Boesveldt et al., 2018; Smits et al., 2011). Our findings are intended to encourage decision-makers to create favorable local governance arrangements and policiesPolicies that continuously support SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) to achieve sustainable transitionTransitions.

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p:
This study employed a qualitative analysis using deductive and inductive approaches. Primary data were collected through face-to-face interview and distributed questionnaire to a total of 18 people. We visited nine projects from GK1 to GK9 (see Table 23.1) and interviewed face to face with one representative from each CBO. CBO is a group composed of community members who managed the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS). They bear the responsibilityResponsibilities of doing daily operational, maintenanceMaintenance, water distribution, and coordinationCoordination. We also collected data from local actors that were province agencyAgencies, district department, subdistrict government, village government, and implementing organization. Data from several actors were gathered using a survey questionnaire comprising open-ended response questions, which was distributed by email in consideration of respondents’ convenience. The list of informants is presented in Appendix 23.1. When used as sources in Results and Discussion, the interview coded numbers are stated in the text inside the square brackets, for example, [10] refers to the interview with province agencyAgencies.Table 23.1

Interviews with the CBO representatives were held from March 2–7, 2021, and those with the external institutions from July 22 to September 2, 2021. The list of questions was constructed beforehand, which consisted of open questions about issues relating to the research questions and the challenges of energy generation transitionTransitions, for example, developmentDevelopments process, operations and maintenanceMaintenance, system malfunctions, support from external stakeholdersStakeholders, policiesPolicies, institutional arrangementInstitutional arrangements, and overall impression of the project. Face-to-face interviews were recorded and transcribed for the analysis. All quotations attributed to the interview are anonymized and masculine personal pronouns are used throughout.

Second, in the analysis of institutional arrangementsInstitutional arrangements, we carried out qualitative analysis from the transcribed interviews and open-ended questionnaires from local actors. Data from the questionnaire were labeled and categorized according to the three indicators: policyPolicies, structure, and management. We present the results in three categories: (1) strong means the variable is fully present in relation to SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS); (2) intermediate is when the variable is present but not aligned with SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS); and (3) weak means the variable does not present at all. The result was triangulated with regulations, lawsLaws, and other secondary data to ensure accuracy in observation. Figure 23.4 shows the method flowchart.Fig. 23.4
Method flowchart
A block diagram depicts the analysis of institutional arrangements. It begins with a semi-structured interview and ends with narrative construction.

sec.title: Results and Discussion
sec.p: This section is presented as follows. First is the analysis of niche management followed by the institutional arrangementsInstitutional arrangements of local actors. At the end, challenges to sustainability transitionSustainability transitions are presented by combining both analyses. Results are shown in the early paragraphs, followed by discussions and references from literature.

sec.title: Niche Management Analysis of Solar Water Pumping Systems

sec.p:
Figure 23.5 captures the survey results regarding the overview of the project, functionality, and the supporting environment of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS), such as the service fee, reserve funds, spare parts, and support from the implementing organization.Fig. 23.5
Project overview
A graph of project survey results in percentage. It depicts insufficient reserve funds and unable to repair and replace the components.

All projects were implemented through the involvement of the external institutions and donors. In the majority, the community participated in public meetings and physical construction. The project was later handed over from the implementing organization to the local community, giving them full responsibilityResponsibilities for operations and maintenanceMaintenance. Local governmentLocal governments, from province to village level, never built any SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) (Fig. 23.6). Problems emerged with the project performance. The majority of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) (8 of 9 or 89%) are currently not functioning. From Table 23.1, it is shown that the average SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) lifetime was 4 years. An accumulation of many factors caused the projects to be stopped. From the interviews, we classified the code, subcode, and abstract into niche management factors (Table 23.2) and the coefficients of co-occurrence in Fig. 23.7. Damage to the electrical components was frequently associated with the need for repair support (0.27) and a lack of reserve funds for repairs (0.19). Moreover, the community needs the support because of the insufficient training they had received (0.20). Throughout the experience on managing the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS), they felt the system failed to deliver the expected performance, which was associated with their preference for an electric utility (0.21).Fig. 23.6
Relationships among actors during SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) project developmentDevelopments
An information diagram represents the involvement of the implementing organization, local government, and local community in the development of the S W P S project later handed over to C B O.Table 23.2
Code, subcode, and abstract
Code and subcode

Keywords

Insufficient training

Theft of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) components
Theft, stolenFig. 23.7
Co-occurrence coefficients between codes
A data set depicts co-occurrence coefficients based on strong, weak, and intermediate relationships. It represents a strong link between electrical component damage and the need for assistance to repair the malfunction.
This section explains the niche management through the indicators of system malfunction, learningLearning process, network building, and vision.

System malfunction. SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) has multiple parts that are exposed to inclement conditions such as bad weather, changes in water level, and human manipulation; therefore, mechanical wear and tear is inevitable. While the design system of each project is different, in general, the pump and controller are the most prone elements of the system. Six projects mentioned problem in the pump (GK1, GK2, GK4, GK6, GK7, GK8) and three projects mentioned problems in the controller/inverter (GK3, GK5, GK 9). Malfunction resulting from theft happened at GK 1 and GK4. In the case of Gunungkidul, most of the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) locations are near to the water source, caves, and forest, far from the community settlement. Theft caused electrical burnouts, which exacerbated the malfunction. Longevity of the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) requires efforts in the repair and replacement of elements when malfunctions occur.

The controller contains sophisticated electronics that must withstand various environmental conditions while isolating the solar PV array from the pump for safety and providing the pump with optimum voltage (Meah et al., 2008a, b). A controller that incorporates an inverter is needed if an AC pump is used. Ideally, the controller/inverter is scheduled to be replaced after 8–12 years (Welsien & Hosier, 2015); however, the average lifetime of the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) in Gunungkidul was only 4 years, far below other reported cases that had been in operation for 10 years in Mexico (Foster et al., 1998) and 15 years in Wyoming, USA (Meah et al., 2008a, b). In other words, the system deteriorated faster than the expected replacement time. Routine operational maintenanceMaintenance faces a huge barrier when there is no support system in the region; hence, the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) quickly become fully nonfunctional.

sec.title: LearningLearning Process
sec.p: The SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) project was developed with strong collaborationCollaboration between external actors and the community. During the project preparation stage, most of the CBOs (89% or 8 of 9 cases) received training in operations and maintenanceMaintenance. The most common training involved wiping the solar panels and checking the pipe [2], [5], [7], [8], [9]. Some CBOs received more advanced training such as GK9. All CBOs said they had insufficient skills for conducting higher level maintenanceMaintenance, such as repairing the pump. Our data show insufficient training to be strongly associated with the need for assistance when malfunctions occur (c-coefficient = 0.20).

Continuous learningLearning is needed in order to improve niche growth. This process aspect was glaringly absent at the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) Gunungkidul. For most installations, technical damage was not investigated further, as there was no skilled technician to assist the community. Several CBOs mentioned the limestone sedimentation that caused damage in the pump [6], [8]. Another CBO mentioned pump failure at low water level [2] and experienced rapid corrosion of the solar PV array situated near the coast [9]. Such problems and their solutions need to be included as part of the learningLearning process in order to improve the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS)’ performance.

The hydrological cycle in karst aquifers has high heterogeneity and is organized by groundwaterGroundwater flow, which needs to be monitored continuously (Bakalowicz, 2005). LearningLearning from several limitations in the field, adjustment in the design technologyTechnologies might be needed to achieve optimum performance and the standardization of best practices (Geels & Deuten, 2006). Difficulties finding skilled human capital within Gunungkidul amplify the urgency to bring technical support and on-going professional advice from outside. Gunungkidul has the lowest Human DevelopmentDevelopments Index among other regions in the province (69.98 of 100) (BPS Provinsi Daerah Istimewa YogyakartaYogyakarta, 2020). The findings in our case studies align with those reported by UNESCAP (UNESCAP, 1991). It is feasible to operate SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) by unskilled personnel; however, skilled engineers are needed for regular technical maintenanceMaintenance. SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) require monthly maintenanceMaintenance checks and annual high-level back-up and support.

sec.title: Network Building
sec.p: The existing SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) network is operated among the CBO, the implementing organization, and village government. As the driver of developmentDevelopments, the implementing organization is expected to deliver assistance. Our research indicates that 89% (8 of 9 cases) do not have direct access to spare parts, meaning they depend on the implementing organization to facilitate the contacts. The majority of CBO representatives said that the spare parts were from outside the province, for example, Surabaya or Semarang, or from the capital city of JakartaJakarta. The pump has been imported from overseas, for example, Lorentz from Germany and Franklin from the United States.

According to those interviewed, almost half of the cases (44%) received support at least once in postconstruction phase. When the institution was willing to facilitate the repairs, the community decision was constrained by limited funds. The collection of user fees became necessary in order to cover the cost of repair. Even though most of the projects (67% or 6 of 9 cases) had collected a service fee, all cases (100%) reported that the reserve fund was insufficient to cover the repair and replacement of components. The fund was only adequate for minor problems, such as fixing broken pipes or to buy battery water. The cost of a replacement unit is far above the community fund. The socio-economic background of the communities, where many are farmersFarmers and day-laborers, makes it difficult to collect additional money. Therefore, component failures were not fixed and SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) operations were not restored.

These findings highlight three consequences. First, the network is not developed between CBOs and higher local governmentLocal governments or broader actors. The CBOs heavily rely on the implementing organization for assistance, such as searching for replacement spare parts. Second, the unavailability of spare parts at a local level means that repair times will be significantly extended because the components have to be shipped from outside the country. Third, although operational cost is very low, if any maintenanceMaintenance costs do happen, then SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) require relatively expensive items such as a replacement pump or controller/inverter (Hjalmarsdottir, 2012); this causes the repair costs to be higher than other water supply systems (UNICEF, 2016). To date, credit from financial institutions or government is not available.

sec.title: Vision and Expectation
sec.p: The SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS), as a new technologyTechnologies in the Gunungkidul RegencyRegencies, was built with an expectation of cheaper water service and minimum operational cost compared with diesel-powered pumps. A lack of commitment was evident in some projects where assistance from the implementing organization was not available at all (56%: GK1, GK2, GK3, GK5, GK8). The difficulties of project management affect the community’s perception about the RE system and preference for an electrical or diesel-powered water utility. The CBOs have a strong interest in electrical utilities (c-coefficient = 0.21) because they are easier to maintain [5], [6], [7], [9] and they believe they are able to manage these units with their minimum skill (0.09) and without external support (0.16).

The promise of technological performance is an essential part of niche developmentDevelopments (Kemp et al., 1998). However, having an accumulation of the above problems, the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) became unreliable and did not meet the users’ expectations. Electric utilities, as an incumbent technologyTechnologies, have the benefits of far longer time in developmentDevelopments and offer convenience of use, lower cost, infrastructureInfrastructures, maintenanceMaintenance network, and regulation (Smith, 2007; Smith et al., 2016); hence, conventional electrical utilities have higher reliability and greater longevity.

sec.title: Analysis of Institutional ArrangementsInstitutional arrangements of Local Actors

sec.p:
The institutional arrangementsInstitutional arrangements vary for each stakeholderStakeholders in the contextInstitutional arrangements of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) management and its transitionTransitions (Table 23.3). The following discussions refer to the contents of table by row number and column, respectively, in brackets; for example, (1, 2) refers to the province agencyAgencies’s roles and responsibilityResponsibilities.Table 23.3

Sub-district government
○ No specific policyPolicies
○ No specific roles
○ No allotted budget
○ Not initiating the collaborative work
4
Village government
Possible to create policyPolicies based on village’s priority
● Have responsibilityResponsibilities to manage assets in their area
Possible to use village funds based on village’s priority
Directly engages with CBO, but yet to broader actors
5
The implementing organization
Have a low-carbon agenda, but no specific mandate to continuously support SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) after handover
Have roles to do experimentation and community service but lack of continuity
Have budget allocation but lack of continuity
● Have broad network and prior experience to engage with many actors
Notes: ●: strong, : intermediate, ○: weak

sec.title: Province AgencyAgencies
sec.p: Institutional mandates play an important part in governmentInstitutional arrangements roles and function to conduct certain programs with a particular approach. In YogyakartaYogyakarta Province, responsibilityResponsibilities for the energy sector is on the province level (1, 1). The province does not have SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) assets and they never built the system. The province government perceives that solar PV for the water sector is currently not effective due to its high initial investmentInvestments cost and the electricity produced is intermittent. Hence, the province level focuses on solar PV utilization for electricity generation and not water pumping.

YogyakartaYogyakarta Province has produced a “Regional Energy Plan 2020–2050” (Government of YogyakartaYogyakarta Province, 2020) that consists of a vision, mission, goals, targets, and strategies for regional energy management. The plan plays a major role as a guideline for local governmentLocal governments, municipalities (kota), and districts (kabupaten) to develop a strategic plan, coordinate across sectors, and for the public to participate in energy sector decisions. From the perspective of RE, the plan mentions installation of solar PVs on building rooftops in government offices, commercial buildings, industry, and public facilities. Because the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) is not stated in the program, the province government’s involvement, budget allocation, and initiative in the issue are limited (1, 2; 1, 3; and 1, 4, respectively).

sec.title: District Department
sec.p: There is no department that manages energy sectors at the district level (2, 1). District departments are responsible for water services that use an electricInstitutional arrangements utility or diesel, and do not consider RE as an electricity source. There is no clear mandate to implement RE in the water sector and RE developmentDevelopments is outside the district’s scope of responsibilityResponsibilities; therefore, local departments only focus on water supplies (2, 2). There is no allotted arrangement in APBD (Regional Fund) for RE projects (2, 3). In the DAK (Special Allocation Fund), which the national governmentNational government transfers to municipalities and is earmarked for national priorities, the allotted arrangement is for the water network and not RE or solar PV. Initiatives for collaborative works in SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) are absent (2, 4).

District government focuses on two programs of the water sector in the Gunungkidul: PDAM in urban areas and the “Water Supply and Sanitation Program for Low-income Communities” (Pamsimas) for rural areas. PDAM has a small part of its systems that uses RE technologyTechnologies but this was a pilot project implemented by external actors (BPPT, 2016; Nestmann et al., 2013).

Pamsimas, a national program initiated by the World Bank and government of Indonesia in 1993, is developed in collaborationCollaboration between community demand and government institutions (The World Bank, 2014). Arguably, there is a possibility to use solar PV in the Pamsimas program. However, budgetInstitutional arrangements allocation per project, which is approximately IDR 240 million (17,000 USD), is inadequate. Additional funding opportunities from the district budget are also limited.

sec.title: Sub-district Government
sec.p: Sub-district level has the role of “guidance (pembinaan) and supervision (pengawasan) of village activities” according to LawLaws Number 23/2014 about Local GovernmentLocal governments. Their work facilitates developmentDevelopments planning meetings and oversees village activity. The sub-district’s policiesPolicies, roles, and initiatives in SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) activities are minimum (3, 1; 3, 2; and 3, 4, respectively). They also do not have an allotted budget for direct activities such as SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) management (3, 3).

Prior research stated that there are challenges due to the lack of capacity in the staff, who commonly carry out purely administrative roles (Syukri, 2016). The research mentioned one of the causes is the absence of detailed regulation about the function and authority of sub-district staff in assisting village governments.

sec.title: Village Government
sec.p: Village government has the strongest roles and responsibilityResponsibilities to manage SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) compared with other government levels (4, 2). When an SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) project is built in their territory, the village government is expected to manage the system [10], [11], [17], [18]. Because the LawLaws Number 6/2014 about “Village” is in force, the village has greater roles and authority to govern autonomously (4, 1). In terms of funding, the national governmentNational government provides a Village Fund (Dana Desa) and district government allocates some budgetInstitutional arrangements as well (4, 3). The village does not put SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) on the priority for an allotted budget due to several considerations. The first derives from the “Vision” section: the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) has failed to meet expectations and seems to not be a reliable system; therefore, the village prefers to build a water supply system based on an electric utility or diesel rather than repairing the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS). Second, the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) has been nonfunctional for a relatively long time; hence, the deteriorated systems require more funds than budgeted.

Regarding engagement among actors in SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) management, we found that village government, which is the lowest government unit, is the only level that directly collaborates with the CBOs that manage SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) and with the implementing organization (4, 4); however, village governments have yet to actively seek broader opportunities to sustain the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS). The upper government levels, that is, the province agencyAgencies, district department, and subdistrict government, are relatively passive and do not initiate collaborative work although they said they are willing to facilitate and coordinate a proposal if any [10], [11], [12], [13].

sec.title: Implementing Organization
sec.p: The implementing organization has technical expertise, resources, and networks to engage with many actors (5, 4). While each institution has different specific policiesPolicies, in general, they want to materialize the potential of RE as a low-carbon technologyTechnologies in rural areas through pilot project experimentation or community service (5, 2). However, such programs often periodically change and do not possess the grand vision and design, making the outcomes of the allotted budget uncertain (5, 3). In all the case studies, when the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) construction is finished and the CBO established, the mandateInstitutional arrangements to sustain the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) is handed over to the CBO and village government (5, 1), leaving the villagers to struggle with technical malfunctions. A clearly defined and written contractual arrangement is needed to clarify each party’s responsibilityResponsibilities (Smits et al., 2011).

sec.title: Challenges of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) Sustainability TransitionSustainability transitions
sec.p: Over almost the last four decades, Indonesia has been unable to successfully implement SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) in the water utility sector. Using an empirical case set of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) at Gunungkidul RegencyRegencies, our analysis focused on local governance, starting with the dynamics of internal niche managementInternal niche management and then the connection to the institutional arrangementsInstitutional arrangements of local actors.

The drivers of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS)developmentDevelopments in Gunungkidul are the external implementing organizations that come from diverse backgrounds: the national agencyAgencies, international donors, universities, and NPOs. The initial cost of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) is beyond the affordability of the rural community, province and district governments’ budgets; hence, none of the projects in Gunungkidul were initiated or developed locally. After construction finished, the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) was handed over to the CBOs, bearing them with the responsibilitiesResponsibilities of management, operations, and maintenanceMaintenance. Community-level organization has been a common approach for rural water supply system in Indonesia through Pamsimas program, which has achieved several success cases of improved water, sanitation, and behavior change (The World Bank, 2014). Rural communities in Indonesia, especially in area having higher scarcity or resources and geographic isolation, commonly have strong cooperation and social ties (Subejo, 2009).

During the preparation stages, eight of the nine CBOs (89%) received training. However, to assume that training would equip the CBOs with enough skill independently is over-simplistic, moreover SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) uses advance technologyTechnologies, not a conventional pump. System malfunctions cannot be handled by the CBOs; as a result, the average project lifetime was only 4 years. Through co-occurrence analysis, we found that the technical damage is related to CBOs’ need for repairs support (c-coefficient = 0.27) and lack of reserve funds for repairs (0.19). They also need the support due to the lack of training they had received (0.20).

During the management of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS), steps for nurturing the niche into sustainability transitionSustainability transitions were not taken. The ideal situation is when the institutions involved in project preparation commit and support the sustainability of the niche. However, from an analysis of institutional arrangementsInstitutional arrangements, it is apparent that their policyPolicies mandate, level of responsibilityResponsibilities, and financing are not aligned to continuously support SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS). Hence, their assistance was discontinued. The YogyakartaYogyakarta province agencyAgencies and Gunungkidul district department were never drivers of the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS)developmentDevelopments; therefore, they perceived the installations to be outside their scope of responsibilityResponsibilities. At the local governmentLocal governments level, networks only exist within the village government as the closest government unit to the CBO.

Without a supportive environment, SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS), as a niche innovationInnovations, was unstable and unsustainable. The barrier of niche adoption in relation to the karst case-specific problem also needs to be properly addressed. The study area of Gunungkidul RegencyRegencies is challenging for the exploration of and lifting of water to the surface, as said by district departments and implementing organization. Reflecting on the rapid deterioration of electrical components, the karst environment is arguably one of the contributing factors to SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) not meeting expectations in terms of longevity. Interviewees mentioned the problems associated with limestone sedimentation and low water level, which are typical in a karst environment. Karst formations develop a distinct hydrological system that needs specific exploration techniques and approaches (Hartmann et al., 2014). Future design configurations should consider such issues to improve SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) durability.

The local governmentLocal governments has acknowledged the benefit of RE and shown interest in applying the technologyTechnologies, as shown in the “Regional Energy Plan 2020–2050” of YogyakartaYogyakarta Province. However, they are yet to involve in water-energy sector and SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) field. From the interview, several barriers existed, such as huge initial investmentsInvestments, perceived uncertaintiesUncertainties of technological performance, and limited public funding [10], [11], [12]. Unavailability of a supportive environment has made it difficult for SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) to compete with incumbent technologyTechnologies, in this case, diesel, and electric utility pumps. Circling back to the vision in project planning, this raises a question regarding how long the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) is expected to last and whether it is regarded as an interim condition prior to grid electrification (Kumar et al., 2019). Small-scale SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) in Gunungkidul are unable to fulfill the vision of a reliable water supply. Consequently, visions to apply solar PV in regional water utilities have not yet emerged.

These above findings reflect three points. First, supportive policyPolicies environment that promotes SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) is unavailable in the municipality; as a result, any initiative to build community-scale SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) project could not be integrated into a certain grand plan, and eventually received little support from the municipalities. Further, when a project successfully implemented, there is a deeper structural problem regarding the tendency to deliver early quantitative, measurable results instead of performance and empirical impacts feedback (Derks & Romijn, 2019). Second, as initiator, the implementing organizations have been focused on replicating SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) installations rather than on building networksGovernancenetworks with local governmentLocal governments and bridging policyPolicies change. Political harmonization and support is extremely crucial, including stakeholdersStakeholders’ engagement, creating forums gathering the actors, routine meeting and consultationConsultation, that induce progress in policyPolicies framework (Sovacool, 2018). Third, province and district governments have not demonstrated an adaptive governance approach toward SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) installations as an opportunity to initiate more action or strategic intervention in low-carbon developmentDevelopments. Study conducted by Morita et al. (2020) mentioned that local governmentLocal governments level of Indonesia has several challenges to achieve sustainable development goalsSustainable Development Goals (SDGs), that are the lack of a coordinated system involving multiple stakeholdersStakeholders, inadequate capacity, experience, resourcesGovernanceresources, and data for implementing and reporting. Shortcoming in local level is arguably related to the perception that national authorities is seen as driving forces of renewables (such as Ministry for Energy and Mineral Resources and state electricity company, or PLN), however the lack of coordinationCoordination between national and subnational decision makers also exist (Marquardt, 2014).

Delegation from national mandate, such as declaring in national planNational plan the obligation to adopt SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) in water utility, will not necessarily achieve success in the implementation of sustainability transitionSustainability transitions. For a localGovernancelocalsinnovationInnovations to be successfully adopted in a broader environment, significant changes are required in the institutional and governance aspect. TransitionTransitions management is an iterative process (Loorbach & Rotmans, 2006), in the process of learningLearning, systematic monitoringMonitoring, and evaluation. The intention to scale should be in stakeholderStakeholders’s mindset and part of the design to assess the scalability of innovationInnovations. Then, the decision to scale is based on the evidence, whether the desirable result is achieved and has potential to expand (Holcombe, 2012). This is not exclusive in our case about the transitionTransitions of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS)technologyTechnologies into water utility, but also in general local RE project that dreamed to pioneer regional energy transitionEnergy transition. A dedicated institution has to be in place to facilitate the transitionTransitions process. RE in general has a barrier to high upfront cost, perceived technologyTechnologies performance uncertaintyUncertainties, and risk (Vallecha et al., 2021). Hence, a strong leadershipLeaderships and committed institution who willing to take risk and advocating change is very crucial (Sovacool, 2018). Due to limited public finance, private sectorPrivate sectorinvestmentInvestments will be very important. In essence, the efficacy of transitionTransitions needs capacity buildingCapacity building, stakeholderStakeholdersparticipationParticipation, policyPolicies alignment, technological learningLearning, and continuous support commitment.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) in Indonesia has been developed as a community-scale project since 1982; however, the technologyTechnologies is yet to be adopted in the water utility sector. Through the lens of governance, we addressed this problem through an analysis of internal niche managementInternal niche management and local actors’ arrangements using a case study in Gunungkidul RegencyRegencies. Our data on SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) projects between 1986 and 2017 show that the average lifetime of the nine SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) projects was 4 years. The discontinuation of support by implementing organizations meant CBOs struggled to overcome system malfunctions. The interviewees repeatedly mentioned that damage to the electrical components was frequently associated with the need for support in order to repair equipment and a lack of reserve funds. The community needs this support due to the insufficient training they received. The iterative process of learningLearning, network building, and articulation of vision was not pursued. Challenges to the adoption of SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) in a karst environment were insufficiently addressed. The network of actors did not extend to higher local governmentLocal governments levels (province and district), whereas at the same time, their initiative to engage was also limited. ResponsibilityResponsibilities rested on village government as the closest government unit to the CBO; however, there was reluctance at this level to prioritize village funding for SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS), because it had failed to meet their vision. As an internal niche, SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS) is seen as unstable and unsustainable by CBOs and local governmentLocal governments; accordingly, there is no vision to apply the technologyTechnologies to the larger water utility.

Solar PV pump technologyTechnologies needs stronger support to compete with diesel and electric utility pumps in the water utility sector. To achieve sustainability transitionSustainability transitions, supportive policyPolicies promoting RE-water sectors should be in place, and more efforts on building vision and committed networks in local actors rather than replicating the number of installations. TransitionTransitions management is an iterative learningLearning cycle; hence, the involved stakeholdersStakeholders need to be dedicated to facilitating and assisting the process. Using insight from our analytical framework and the Gunungkidul case, it could be helpful for parties to identify similar cases of community-scale RE projects in rural settings.

We consider the following limitations in our research. First, we did not explore diverse aspects such as the market, industry, science, culture, and infrastructureInfrastructures. Second, we did not delve into the national and local linkage of water–energy policyPolicies. Future research in this area will strengthen the argument about the SWPSSolar water pumping system (SWPS)developmentDevelopments trajectory from a multilevel perspective. Sustainability transitionSustainability transitions is a continuous and long-term effort that needs a combination of strength and commitment from different level of government structures, from national to local level.

ack.title: Acknowledgment
ack.p: We deeply thank all interviewees who shared their experiences, views, and time with us. We are also very grateful to Ameylia Puspita Rosa, Naufal Fattah Tastian, Freegita Istihadi, and Septia Latifah for their assistance in the fieldwork. We thank Kultip Suwanteep for her feedback.

Dana Alokasi Khusus, or Special Allocation Fund

fn.p: Decent Drinking Water = Drinking water with a minimum distance of 10 m to a waste disposal site sourced from pipes, drilling wells/pumps, protected wells, protected springs, including rainwater; it does not include bottled water, water from street vendors, water sold through tanks, well water, or unprotected springs [8].
